content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The question is unique and simply very nice.

Hello Adam. I like your contribution.
I have two things I want to comment on.

1. I would give an unsorted list of integers to make it slightly harder, but this is not nessesary for my approval.

2. I think the statement could be written a bit clearer:
"You are given N SORTED Integers, and you have to find the first element that occurs 25% of the time or more. If there are none, print -1." 
This way it is (imo) easier to understand, and less to read.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting contribution,  I like the concept and there are also a lot of testcases
A fine clash, yes you really should make it fastest as well.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very fun and very interesting question!

1. Output description should mention the -1 case.
2. Example mentions an array, but the input is not an array
3. [[E]] is not a variable, should not mention about it
4. rephrase "You are given integers E, SORTED " => "You are given [[N]] sorted integers"
love this idea, very beginner-friendly and easy to understand!

1. Your statement does not define when -1 should be output, and no test cases cover the -1 scenarios. Yet your solution code and one of the validators show that -1 may be the required output.
2. The description in the Input section "An integer n" is wrong.
3. Why always 10 numbers are given as Input? Can't there be more or fewer numbers?
4. Why numbers given are always sorted? Can't they be unsorted?
5. Why the constraints 1<=E<=102? Can't E be zero, negative or bigger numbers?

Thank you for your feedback. They always have to be sorted as a more optimal solution can be used rather than if there scattered then it would be more complicated. I can edit the constraints that's fine. Will fix the statement and the description section.
Thank you!

Thank you for your feedback!
I made it so that the user had to populate the array himself.
Just implemented the rest. :)

Hello! 
Thank you so much for your feedback! You are totally correct!
Will make the changes ASAP and add more test cases.

Making these changes will add it to shortest mode?
Agree
Thank you!

Hello!

Thank you for your feedback :)
Will get that sorted right away :)

Yeah for 1, it would have a different approach the whole point of this, is to use a more efficient method since they are sorted :)
Thank you!
Thank you!
Done :)
I fixed from 1-3. I won't change 4 and 5 as I don't think its that big of a deal. I would appreciate your input on the changes :)

As per contribution guidelines, "Each validator should check the same case as the corresponding test".
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/test-cases

The issue of the two situations where -1 is the required output is still not covered in any test cases and hence should be fixed based on what I quote above.

Also, the names of one test case and one validator are missing.

The statement does not explain what 25% means when the number of numbers is not a multiple of 4.

In fact, I can't even understand what you mean by 25% even when the number of numbers is a multiple of 4. For example, in Test 4, there are 16 numbers, I would think the number which appears 4 times should be the answer, while in fact your answer appears 6/16 (≠ 25%) of the time.
Yeah the numbers need fixing. Does the validator need to be there? I see some test cases where there's only 4 tests.
The validators are the hidden test cases which determine your actual score when you submit your code. The test cases are not. Both test cases and validators must be present.
In regards to test 4 should at least be 25% there can be more.
I see

For test 4,   so t = 16 / 4 = 4 , we subtract it from n when creating the for loop and then because its sorted we check if that element is ==  to the ith - t element, if it is that means its there 25% of the time. Its not always 4 times, it depends on the size. Sometimes it can show more than 25% of the time because we need at least 25% not exactly.
You have to revise your statement accordingly.
Be more specific? I gave an example, what else should I include ?
If you mean "more than 25%", state it that way.

Oh yes, you're right. Just fixed it. Thank you for your feedback :)
Is there anything else that needs clarification?

Thanks. Further comments below:

In the statement "that you will have to put in an array or list" can be deleted.

The name of Validator 4 is missing.

Output should be: The element "in" E that occurs 25% or MORE of the time (because E refer to ALL the integers, not just one).

Add a constraint: Either no integer or one integer appears 25% or more of the time.

Add a variety of test cases and validators where:
(a) the element required to be output may be zero, negative or numbers greater than 9. In other words, the constraints should be fully utilised.
(b) there are zero integers (you had such a case previously).
(c) the elements other than the answer may appear more than once. I mean, while an example is given in the statement itself ([1,2,2,6,6,6,6,7,10]), none of the test cases and validators right now have similar properties.

(Just a sidenote: Your clash is actually no different from finding the integer of maximum frequency.)
Okay, will add the feedback. You're right there's no difference but if its sorted, you can solve it in a more efficient way.
Completed a,b,c

Thanks.
Now the name of Test 3 is missing...?
And I still can't see any case of zero integers. If you aren't going to have any, please amend the constraint as 0<N<=16.
Done :)
OK, no further comments for the time being, thanks.
